CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States July 20, 2020
CommentsContent: Cooks both sides at the same time. Love it

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States June 23, 2013
CommentsContent: I saw an ad for this in a magazine, and used the QR code to visit the website and learn more. It's either hot & humid or cold & yucky where we live, so we don't do as much grilling as I'm used to from growing up in Southern California. I had one of the original George Foreman grills from YEARS ago, but it was a pain to clean so I stopped using it. I was debating another GF grill, since they now have models with interchangeable plates.Then I saw that ad for the Griddler. I read the reviews on amazon as well as other sites. I LOVED the fact that the plates could be washed in the dishwasher. I knew Cuisinart was getting a really good reputation for quality kitchen appliances. Finally, Amazon had the best price by $20. Done!Yes, the plates really do wash up well in the dishwasher--they can also be handwashed. I've done both several times. It's incredibly easy to switch out the plates--grill ribs on one side, flat griddle (with rim so no spillage) on the other. I also purchased the waffle plates, and they made great Belgian waffles--much easier than with my Oster spinning waffler.Flip the center switch to choose the grill or griddle function (the manual explains what to use for cooking different items), and its light turns red so you know it's on. The coils under the plates begin heating. Flip the dial for either the grill or griddle feature  (whichever one you put the center switch on) to the temperature you want. I wasn't used to using degrees for temperature on a griddle, but it's easy to play with it and see what works best. When it's heated to your desired temperature, a green light on that switch will light.Using the grill plates: I made hamburgers and my daughter made a panini. We used top & bottom at the same time, as for paninis (made the hamburgers grill more quickly--no need to turn them).Using the griddle plates: We've made several grilled cheese sandwiches. Be sure to open the Griddler to the flat position (there's a little button on the side), so that you get the "floating hinge" effect and don't squash your sandwich.Using it flat: I used it flat to cook eggs--it worked really well.One nice thing you can do is, when your food is almost ready, just turn the middle switch to OFF, and let the residual heat finish cooking your food. Then you don't have to worry about leaving it on too long.I am surprised some people had problems with the drip tray. It tucks underneath in an angled manner (sounds weird--you'll understand when you see it). Mine contained all of the hamburger grease really well--no mess on my kitchen counter. I love that it tucks away flatly--I'm just afraid I'll forget to check it and get rid of the grease because it's so unnoticeable! :DGet. Enjoy. Love! If you get a lemon (because lemons happen!), just return it for a new one, because this is a very well-made product.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 14, 2014
CommentsContent: I recently purchased this and use it at least 3 to 4 times a week. Great for the winter months where I don't feel like being stuck in the cold or cooking in the dark. Makes a great steak and other meats. I like how the grease exits through the back instead of rolling right at you like other griddles. The sear functionality works great. The product is sturdy and good looking, would recommend for anyone.

CommentsTitle: Uneven Temperature between top and bottom plates
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 31, 2018
CommentsContent: I purchased this as a Christmas gift, but I am very disappointed in the performance of the unit.  When making a panni, the temp difference between the plates was significant.  Top was about 100 degrees lower than the bottom plate, making me having to flip the panni.  The Cuisinart brand used to stand for quality, but not anymore.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States May 15, 2011
CommentsContent: Update 3-20-13 - the plastic drip tray does not completely capture the grease. Drips all over the counter making a mess.The knob for controlling the heat has to be manually held on once it gets hot, otherwise it shuts off on you. Clips holding unit together very cheap. Haven't broken yet but expect them to. I wouldn't buy again. Very disappointed. The waffle iron did work out, but overall just very unhappy with what I thought was going to be a long lasting purchase turning into a piece of high priced junk

CommentsTitle: ... grill a few weeks ago to help us have easy options for cooking in our small apartment
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States October 23, 2014
CommentsContent: My husband and I ordered this grill a few weeks ago to help us have easy options for cooking in our small apartment.  We LOVE it!  We can grill a couple of thawed chicken breasts (using the contact grill function) in seven minutes!  And I've had a grilled cheese every day this week for lunch.  We've also cooked pancakes, flank steak, and plenty else.  My husband is impressed that the grill cooks so evenly, and I am thrilled that the plates are so easy to clean!  We were totally prepared to use the dishwasher and even let them get a little yucky, but replace them in a year or two, but after probably 20 uses, they are still brand new looking with hardly any scraping or scrubbing!  Our only complaint is that most of our cooking juices don't seem to travel to the small hole in the back of the grill to drain into the drip tray.  We're not totally convinced that this isn't because our counter is uneven, though.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 13, 2021
CommentsContent: My son loves the versatility and ease of cleaning!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 16, 2018
CommentsContent: Love this appliance! I’ve used the grill side to do pork chops, the flat side to do French toast and we made some pressed sandwiches, as well. The only issue was the top bun slid forward when closing the press, so I had to manipulate it while closing so it would sit right and squish the whole sandwich down. Great product otherwise!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 19, 2006
CommentsContent: I've had this grill for about 3 months now. I've had other grills and this is head and shoulders above anything I've ever tried. The cooking surfaces pop out for very easy cleaning. The heat is high enough with the sear setting that juices never run off! Steaks are perfect in as little as 2.5 minutes for thinner steaks, but I've turned it down and cooked 2" pork chops for much longer and they turn out just as juicy and perfectly delicious. I'm totally sold on this unit and plan to buy one for my daughter at college.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 5, 2019
CommentsContent: not the easiest to clean, there are better out there but this was a quick buy, will definitely upgrade and spend a little more for nicer next time

CommentsTitle: Not up to Cuisinart quality; Customer Service non-existent
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 27, 2011
CommentsContent: I own several Cuisinart products and have been pleased with them. However, the Griddler is definitely a product that probably should not bear the Cuisinart name.Cons:1) The 2nd or 3rd time I used the Griddler I set the Grill/Panini knob to High and turned the selector switch to Grill/Panini to pre-heat the unit. After several minutes I checked the unit and the ready light on the Griddle knob (not the Grill knob) was lit. Since I had not used the unit as a griddle yet, the Griddle knob was turned to lowest setting (200 degrees) so this is what the Griddler pre-heated to. So even though I had the selector switched to Grill/Panini, the heat had to be controlled by the Griddle knob. Although this knob/selector issue only happened that one time it indicates a problem which could be of concern (what if the opposite occurred; thinking I was pre-heating to 200 degrees but instead it heated to "SEAR").2) I contacted Customer Service regarding the above and NEVER got a response back from them.3) Today I used the unit as a griddle for the first time and set the knob to 350 degrees. I started off cooking some Butterball turkey bacon (which is very thin and cooks fairly quickly) on both halves of the griddle. All was going well and after removing the bacon from one side of the unit I ladled out pancake batter on that side. I removed the bacon from the other half and put more bacon on. After a couple minutes I noticed the pancakes were not "bubbling" and the bacon was not sizzling. I touched my finger quickly to one of the plates (like you would to test an iron) and it felt warm to almost hot. When I turned the Griddle knob down the indicator light relit at almost 200 degrees. I ended up having to turn off the Selector switch and then turn it back on with the Griddle knob turned to 400 degrees to get it to start heating back up. Definitely an issue with the knobs and temperature control.4) As at least one other reviewer has mentioned, for paninis, the top self-adjusts but only after it has contacted the food with enough pressure to release the top from its' detents. What this results in is the top slice of bread (and whatever layers of ingredients you have) being pushed forward. So you essentially end up with a "leaning tower of panini." I overcome this by using an oven-mitted hand (yes, the top does get very hot) to situate the top parallel to the bread as I close the cover. Even then the top still has lateral motion and will result in a slightly skewed sandwich.5) The drainage lips do not line up well with the drip tray. Thankfully I have not cooked any fatty/greasy foods but have ended up with puddles of poultry juices on the counter top.6) It may seem petty but maybe some sort of indicator light when the drip tray has liquid in it. When you are cooking something and it is done, you usually turn off the unit and leave to serve/eat the food. Several times I have gone to move the unit after it has been off for a while only to spill the entire contents of the tray. Luckily, as I mentioned above, my tray has pretty much only contained poultry juices which is easier to clean up than a puddle of molten, or even slightly congealed, fat. An indicator light that stays lit until the drip tray is emptied would be a nice reminder.7) The top does get very hot. Why couldn't the unit have been constructed with a double hull or some sort of liner? Hey, I would rather have a layer of asbestos paper sandwiched (no pun intended) between a double metal shell than burns/welts on my fingers from incidental contact. You definitely don't want the Griddler anywhere within a child's reach.8) The knobs/dials are very flimsy and do not feel like quality parts. Cheaps parts used for temperature control are going to fail quicker than quality parts; cheap moving parts are going to fail quicker than quality parts.Pros:1) I love, love, love sandwiches and it is nice that I can thin slice some chicken breast and toss it and some veggies onto the grill surface, close the top and minutes later remove the chicken and veggies, place them on bread with some cheese, close the top and several more minutes later have a decent chicken and veggie hot sandwich. I am not much of a red meat eater but will eventually try this for hamburgers.2) I cooked marinated chicken breast for 3 or 4 days in a row. I did not bother to clean the plates each time (sort of like coffee lovers who do not wash their cups) but instead just did a quick scrape with the included tool and days later when I looked at the plates I thought they would never be clean again. The grill scraper and a spray of hot water took care of the burnt on marinades in less than a minute. Most time I don't even need to wash the plates, but just wipe them with a cloth.3) The plates cool down very quickly once the unit is shut off (which is really no surprise considering there is absolutely no insulation anywhere near the plates/heating elements).4) Although the plates are very light and seem to be very fragile (they honestly feel like they could snap in your hands) they are in fact quite durable.5) The plate clips hold the plates very well and the release buttons work like a charm. I really have to question other reviewers claims that the clips have melted, my clips are made from heat resistant plastic, very similar to if not the same as the scraper. My clips do not show even the slightest hint of heat damage/melting.6) Anyone who has read my review of the "Pizzazz" will know I like using products for multiple purposes. I have used the griddle plates to heat a bunch of shrimp poppers (dumped half the bag out onto the plate, evened them out and closed the top. Shortly afterwards I had hot, slightly charred, crispy poppers. The same can be done with fish fillets as there seems to be enough space when using the griddle plates to cook the fish but not flatten them out. I was out of bread so I opened a tube of crescent rolls but left them flat. Placed them on the griddle plate and closed the cover. Minutes later I had golden brown crescent "bread" which I then used to make a couple panini sandwiches.Comments:1) Paninis are just another stupid craze everyone seems to have to be in on. I have a sandwich maker but that tends to make more of a sealed (pocket) sandwich. The Griddler does a nice job of heating/toasting sandwiches, with or without grill marks.2) The Griddler could just have easily been developed with only one knob. I am very sure that setting the Selector at Griddle and the knob at 350-400 degrees is absolutely no different than setting the Selector to Grill-Panini and the knob to High. It is just more parts that are subject to fail and create a potential hazard. C'mon, how many people are going to want PRECISE temperature control with a product like this. We don't need a dial that can be set to between 275-300 degrees. Cuisinart could have used a quality detent dial; Off, 200/Warm, 250/Low, 300/Med, 350/Med-Hi, 400/High, 450/Sear. In fact, if you look at the Griddle knob you will see the dial is linear (50 degree major increments, 25 degree minor increments) until you get to the highest settings which changes to a major increment of 25 degrees (12.5 minor). Since a linear potentiometer should not suddenly go non-linear, the degree markings on the face of the Griddler pretty much mean nothing. Maybe someday I will test the settings against actual temperature. What would have been nice is a dial to allow only one side to be turned on so you are not heating up both plates when only one is going to be used.3) The top could have been designed so the top stays parallel and comes down on the food at a more vertical angle.Cuisinart should go back and rethink this one. I have used mine quite a bit but don't like the little quirks, especially the uncertainty of when the unit is going to "think" it is griddling when I have set it to grilling. Guess what, if you set the Selector to Griddle but flip the plates over you are now grilling. Having 3 cheap dials serving the purpose of one quality dial (or two if you add the ability to turn off one side) is stupid and wasteful.Add some insulation, make the side plate clips out of a material that is resistant to EXTREME heat so no one can complain the clips melted, and, dammit, answer consumer queries/complaints/feedback.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 22, 2021
CommentsContent: That's how my nephew describes his wife going crazy with this thing. They love it

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 20, 2021
CommentsContent: Great grilled and panini sandwiches heaters

CommentsTitle: Beats my old George Foreman Grill!
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 25, 2014
CommentsContent: I had a George Forman grill for years that I loved.  When the handles broke off of "George" I tried to replace it and TWO of the same grill malfunctioned.  I purchased this Cuisinart and am glad i did!  I love the exchangeable plates.  I have the waffle ones and my boys are thrilled with the waffles I can now make.  The only downside it the way the grease or waffle batter will drip a bit, even with the tray in place.  I recommend placing it on top of a cookie sheet on the counter.  The even heating and great design are worth it.  Very versatile!

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States February 9, 2013
CommentsContent: I have used this product for years and it's still going.  I was looking for something easy to use and easy to clean.  This certainly meets both criteria.  It works very well, it is very easy to use, it comes with a menu of suggestions on a variety of paninis and because of the detachable plates, it is extremely easy to clean.I found the price point very reasonable too.  It was cheaper on Amazon than at the store.  Overall a very good product.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States August 23, 2019
CommentsContent: My family enjoys the variety of cooking they can do with this.  It can be washed in dishwasher and cleans easily.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 23, 2013
CommentsContent: Just got this about a week ago and we've already made Reuben sandwiches, pork chops, and fried up some Spam on it.  Easy to clean with the removable plates.  Very easy to use - - similar to the dials on our oven.  Grease catcher works very well and, again, easy to clean.  Just ordered the waffle plates directly from Cuisinart even though the site said it has an estimated shipping date of May.  It'll be worth the wait since they only charge $39.99 for the set.

CommentsTitle: When making sandwiches this sucks. When I want to flatten the top so ...
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States March 10, 2017
CommentsContent: I use this thing all the time. I will however say I am not a fan of the way the top comes down. It tends to slide stuff forward. When making sandwiches this sucks. When I want to flatten the top so it comes down evenly, I have to wear an oven mitt. Overall however its great.

CommentsTitle: This is not the Cuisinart that once deserved five stars
CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 22, 2020
CommentsContent: It simply cannot maintain heat levels - a grilled sandwich is just not "grilled" - and I have tried preheating it on several settings and still no success so save your $$$ - I have been a Cuisinart fan for years but no more

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States January 11, 2019
CommentsContent: This thing is great. We replaced an old George Forman grill with this and glad we did! Removable griddles are amazing, lays out flat if needed, heats perfectly. Very happy with this and have used it a lot.

CommentsDate: Reviewed in the United States December 26, 2010
CommentsContent: Used it the day I received it to grill a New York strip steak.  4 minutes and perfectly medium rare.  Used it to make a panini for lunch the following day. Once again, beautifully and quickly grilled.Cleanup up exceptionally easy.Haven't used it as a griddle or in the open position yet but I'm sure it will perform well.For those who broke the handle, there's enough weight to press a panini without forcing the lid down. Panini's are not meant to be totally squashed.
